DEDICATION ■■''.' ■'-. 1 ,■-'■'" ' . ■ In due recognition of the untiring, voluntary ' efforts of thousands of public spirited farmer cor- "■ respondents serving without pay! and the conscien - tious work of the assessors who take the annual census of agriculture, this 1.930 report of Neliras - ka Agricultural Statistics is dedicated. The plan of taking an annual census of agri - culture was. advocated for years by the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture.. In 1597, a law was passed -making it a duty of assessors to collect agri - cultural statistics at the time of the assessment of property. This work was transferred from the Bu - reau of Labor to the Board of Agriculture in ifll.'S and to the Nebraska Department of Agriculture in 1919 where it still remains. This work has been developed until, it has reached a high state of efficiency. No other state has a better system. The annual report carries from two to three times the material carried by the average state report. The cost is less than that of the average state for this work despite the high agricultural rank and the cost is less than Iy, cents per taxpayer. The state census is inexpensive, accurate and timely, the latter two- elements giving it the fullest measure of usefulness. The acreage on the cur - rent year's planting is gathered during April, May and June and is available in township, county anil state form by June 20, two and a half months' after the census begins. Contrast this with the federal census for 1929 acreage which is not yet available in full at this date, April 1, 1931. The splendid success of this work is due to three things. First, the public spirited farmers who serve without pay and the assessors to whom this issue, is dedicated. Second, the efficiency of the office staff which is trained in the operation of high speed machinery. Third, adequate and suf - ficient modern equipment. These factors have en- , a bled the Division not only to increase, its output ' tremendously without increased cost, but also to get timely publicity before part of its value is lost. Three cheers for our splendid cooperators.

DOLLARS [ ~ I 1 1 PER 100 Sv_ poOnds >w 6l''lfLllll I I I I I I I | i i 80 ?.5 90 9.5 | 0 0 LIVE WEIGHT or SLAUGHTER IN BILLIONS Of POUNDS THE SUPPLY OF BEEP DETERMINES LAROELY THE PRICE A [rather, definite relationship between supply and demand of beef exists as manifested by Hie above charj. The base or bottom line gives the quantity of beef slaughtered m billions of pounds under federal inspection. The figures at the left K ivc the price m dollars per hundred ' pounds of hecf. The quantity slau K htered and the price paid for beef cattle arc given for the years 1922 to 1928, inclusive.' The diagonal } line between the dots represents the average re - lationship between the price and the supply. and demand. Observe that m 1928 when the supply had fallen to nearly 8.0n0.M0,000 lbs that the price exceeded $9 per hundred pounds. The low point m price during this period was reached m 1925 when the supply was nearly 10,000.0(10,000 lbs.. resulting m a price below ,«7 per hundred pounds. Apparently the supply is the leading factor affecting price. The demand is affected by competition from pork, million, poultry, employment and business conditions. CATTLE SUPPLY CAN BE ADJUSTED TO STABILIZE PRICE Vast records show that cattle production runs m cycles of 12 to 15 years duration, or about three (imps that of the hog production cycle. | The cause of these cycles is the trend tit price to which production responds as m the case of ho S s. The response- of production to price naturally takes much more time for cattle than for ho R s or sheep. Cattle production is a long time enter - prise. W hen the low point m production is reached, the price of cattle is high. High price stimulates production. Increased production calls for increased breeding stock One season is necessary for gestation t... produce a heifer calf, and nearly two years more for this calf to reach breeding, age. A.ld to this about three more years to raise and fatten a steer, making a tota Jo six years i., increase production. Fly this time prices will have reached the peak or high pomu In the meantime farmers continue to save heifer calves for breeding not only during the period of high prices but for two or three years after production reaches a high point that causes declining prices and finally production follows. Reduced production again stimulates price and another cattle production cycle begins. m^mm^^V T^* "V " T"' There "™ a hiR " "" int '"' P""**""" m ! IBVJ.yj, ijw-Oj, 1919-20. Lowj points of production were reached m 1897, 1912 and 1928 At present, cattle are on an increasing production point of the cycle with decreasing price." The war demand for beef made the last upward swing m cattle production rather marked. Not only will this factor be lacking m the present upward swing of cattle production, but sheep have re- Placed cattle on part of the range, formerly used for cattle. However, this is a time to watch cattle production closely m a,i endeavor to check it before the supply again reacts m, avoraWv I on . e,farm price. A study of past records and charts as well as current ,Ut ££ SSffi terially m regulating production and stabilizing price. 15

Potatoes: relation between total production and u.s. farm price, 1920-1928 CENTS - ■ , . -; per I I r ■■ 1 r~ : i I I BUSHEU FARM PRICES ADJUSTED TO 1928 LEVEL OF FOOD PRICES ' ' ' 180 =^25 J J 160 — ■- ; -^^___j 140 ' ~ '■ 120 ■ : 100 '■ _ ■___ GO I ' 1 : — I 1 — J I I t»Sw I 300 320 340 360 380 400 420 - 440 460 480 U.S. PRODUCTION OF POTATOES - MILLION BUSHELS THE SUPPLY OF POTATOES IS THE LEADINO FACTOR DETERMINING PRICE The above chart presents rather positive evidence that the supply of potatoes determines Hie price. Note that m 1928 when the production exceeded 460,000,0:0 liushels that the price ' was approximately $0.60 per bushel. Note also that m 1925 when the production had dropped to nearly 320,000,000 bushels that the price was around $1:81) or three times as high m 1928 the year of unusually high production. Observe also, that m 1920 when the production was slightly below 400,000,000 bushels that the price was approximately $1.10 per bushel. Note the other years . by following directly downward from the dot to the production Riven ill millions of bushels at the base of the chart and also from the dot to the extreme left .where the; corresponding price can be noted. It is apparent that the price is almost directly proportional to' the quantity produced. * ™'™ ? ricC wolll(l >>ml c*e *P ect if tllc ero P was 360,000,000 bushels? Simply follow the 300,000,000 bushel production line upward lo the point that- it intersects the heavy black line and from this point follow the line horizontally to the left which shows about $1.40. Other lactors beside supply affect the price, but the supply is the leading factor. CAN THE SUPPLY OF POTATOESBE ADJUSTED TO lIRIN'd FAVORABLE PRICE To a certain extent, the production can lie adjusted to meet demand and a favorable price, by avoiding greatly increased or greatly reduced acreage. There has been a tendency m the past for farmers to plant heavily" following a year of low production and high prices. This usually resulted m too large production and low prices. As a result of low prices again, a reduced acreage was planted the next year. This syslem gave. a large supply to sell when prices were low and a small supply when prices were high. In general, the best policy is to plant about the normal acreage each year. At times, some departure from normal planting is desirable. The potato planting survey made m February each year offers considerable assistance m the way of adjusting acreage. This survey is made before the planting is started and gives the intended acreage for each state and for the country as a wliolc. II the intended acreage is considerably above or considerably below the normal, farmers have an opportunity to change their acreage accordingly. During the past two or three years, some of the potato growers m the commercial sections have made a study of potato production and price and have adopted the policy of increasing ' tlicir acreage following a year of large production and low price and decreasing their acreage following a year of low production and high price. This has had a tendency to more uniform production each year than formerly. Weather often plays a large part m production and while it may upset the best laid acreage plans, nevertheless, the exercise of care m avoiding too large or tuo small planting as shown by the planting intentions survey will help materially to obtain maximum financial returns. 68

IN BILLIONS OF POUNDS THE SUPPLY OF PORK IS THE LARGEST PRICE DETERMINING FACTOR Contrary to the belief of some farmers, the supply of pork largely determines the price of hogs raiher than alleged packer manipulation. The demand for pork exerts an influence also anil the combined effects of these two factors makes the price of hogs. The above charts offers <|uite conclusive evidence as to this fact. ■ Hy studying this chart, you will observe for the hog crop yeir, 1925-26 the packers received slightly more than 9,503,000,000 pounds of live hogs. (Run a line down from the dot ot 1925-26 production perpendicular to the base or lower horizontal line upon which the graduations of live hogs purchased is given m billions of pounds. Tllis indicates slightly more than 9,500,000,000 pounds uf live hogs. Run another line from this dot horizontally to the left price line. This indicates slightly more than $12 per 100 pounds paid for hogs.) Next, observe the dot indicating 192J-24 production and price. Note the slaughter was high, nearly 12,000,000,000 pounds and the price was below $8 per 10J pounds. • The heavy diagonal line represents the average price lor a given production for the period of time included m this chart. 1922 to 1928, Had the demand been constant, it is highly prob - able all of the dots would have fallen on the line. Among other things, the demand is affected by competitive meats such as beef, mutton and poultry, by business conditions which affect the buying power of consumers, condition of employment, etc. However, the lesson to be learned is that supply is the leading factor determining price and except for slight variations m demand, it is almost directly proportional to the supply. CAN FARMERS ADJUST THE SUPPLY OF HOGS TO BRING A SATISFACTORY PRICE? ' It is possible for fanners to adjust the supply of hogs to the demand to a very marked ex - tent am) to obtain more satisfactory prices. It* cannot be done under the haphazard method of blind production whereby far.mers breed more sows when the price is high and less sows when the price is low. Past records show that method has resulted m four or live year hog cycles, 2'/i years of descending and 2'/j years ot ascending price. This is brought about from the fact that when production is high and prices low, the farmer breeds less sows. Soon' he finds production low and prices high and he 'begins to increase breeding. Hy the time he gets the production up again, the prices are low and so on through the next cycle. Fortunately, it is nithill the power of the farmers to correct this situation to a large extent. The solution to this problem oi maintaining steady and maximum price is largely m adjustment of production which can Ik* accomplished .by the pig surveys. The June pig survey gives the size oi the spring pig crop as compared with past years.- The farmer can determine whether production is high, low or normal. The survey also gives the plans for breeding for the fall pig crop. The farmer therefore has the necessary information to adjust the supply. The December pig survey gives the information on the size of (lie (all pig crop and the breeding intentions for the gpriug crop. ■ .' . 80

AH farm products consumed on the farm such as beef, pork, milk, butter and garden crops are omitted from this calculation. On the fiscal year basis, crop sales are from the crop produced in the calendar year preceding the fiscal year date. AH grain and crop values except those of barley and rye are based on actual railway shipments; values of barley and rye being based on the percentage of the crop shipped out of the county ill which grown. The value o( crops sold locally for feeding purposes, is purposely omitted from thete estimates as it is accounted for in the value received from the sale of livestock. Livestock values are based up;m actual market receipts from Nebraska, weighted on the basis of the average monthly prices which Nebraska farmers receive for each kind of livestock. Butterfat and cream values are derived from butterfat prices applied to figures of total manu - facture as reported by dairy manufacturies in the state. Poultry values are based on conserva - tive estimates and the mid-month prices to the farmer. The following figures arc conservative^ Due to the fact that figures on the amount of Brain sold direct to mills by farmers arc not available, these values are not included; likewise the value oi whole milk sold in towns and cities and the value of butter sold locally as well as that of several other items which cannot be closely estimated arc not included in the following computation. 116
